newsItems.title: Gaza war latest: Ceasefire will begin when Israel ratifies deal tonight, says Netanyahu - as breakthrough celebrated | World News | Sky News
newsItems.content:
Breaking Breaking

# Gaza war latest: Ceasefire will begin when Israel ratifies deal tonight, says Netanyahu - as breakthrough celebrated

Israel and Hamas have signed off on the first phase of the Gaza peace plan, which will see hostages returned from Gaza. As a result of the breakthrough, Israel says a ceasefire is expected to apply after its government ratifies the deal tonight. Watch and follow the latest below.

Thursday 9 October 2025 12:46, UK

- [Israel-Hamas war](https://news.sky.com/topic/israel-hamas-war-10864) - [LIVE](https://news.sky.com/topic/live-7029)

Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player Watch Sky News coverage as first phase of Gaza peace plan is agreed

[Why you can trust Sky News](https://news.sky.com/info/policies-and-standards)

##### Key points

- [Israel and Hamas agree to first phase of peace plan - what you need to know](https://news.sky.com/story/gaza-war-latest-israel-intercepts-latest-gaza-flotilla-as-israel-peace-talks-continue-in-egypt-13443931?postid=10321799#liveblog-body) - [Ceasefire begins only after Israeli government ratifies deal](https://news.sky.com/story/gaza-war-latest-israel-intercepts-latest-gaza-flotilla-as-israel-peace-talks-continue-in-egypt-13443931?postid=10321061#liveblog-body) - [Watch: Moment Trump tells hostage relatives](https://news.sky.com/story/gaza-war-latest-israel-intercepts-latest-gaza-flotilla-as-israel-peace-talks-continue-in-egypt-13443931?postid=10319737#liveblog-body) - ['There's no home, but we still want to go home' - Gazans rejoice](https://news.sky.com/story/gaza-war-latest-israel-intercepts-latest-gaza-flotilla-as-israel-peace-talks-continue-in-egypt-13443931?postid=10320836#liveblog-body) - [Netanyahu hails 'great day for Israel'](https://news.sky.com/story/gaza-war-latest-israel-intercepts-latest-gaza-flotilla-as-israel-peace-talks-continue-in-egypt-13443931?postid=10319126#liveblog-body) - [Hamas calls on Trump to ensure Israel sticks to deal](https://news.sky.com/story/gaza-war-latest-israel-intercepts-latest-gaza-flotilla-as-israel-peace-talks-continue-in-egypt-13443931?postid=10319085#liveblog-body) - Live reporting by Nick Alipour

##### Analysis

- [Yalda Hakim: Why now for Netanyahu?](https://news.sky.com/story/gaza-war-latest-israel-intercepts-latest-gaza-flotilla-as-israel-peace-talks-continue-in-egypt-13443931?postid=10319907#liveblog-body) - [Trump 100 podcast: Has he really stopped the war?](https://news.sky.com/story/gaza-war-latest-israel-intercepts-latest-gaza-flotilla-as-israel-peace-talks-continue-in-egypt-13443931?postid=10320010#liveblog-body) - [Could Trump win Nobel Peace Prize?](https://news.sky.com/story/gaza-war-latest-israel-intercepts-latest-gaza-flotilla-as-israel-peace-talks-continue-in-egypt-13443931?postid=10319618#liveblog-body)

## Ask a question or make a comment

11:43:12 Submit your questions for our live Q&A We're hosting a live Q&A to answer all your questions around the ceasefire deal in Gaza.Our US correspondent Mark Stone will join our correspondent Alistair Bunkall at 4.30pm - do join us.Until then, submit your questions in the box above (scroll up just a bit) and we'll do our best to get to them.

12:46:00 Agreement is a success for Israel's government, foreign minister claims Israel's foreign minister, Gideon Sa'ar, has claimed the agreement with Hamas is a success for his government in what he called "historic moments".They had "succeeded in restoring Israel's image of strength in the region and the world", Sa'ar wrote on X, citing military operations against Hamas, Hezbollah and Iran.Sa'ar framed it as the government fulfilling "its commitment to freeing the hostages" - despite consistent calls from Donald Trump to reach a deal.He also warns "Israel's challenges are not over", as Hamas's rule in Gaza and its threat to Israel would have to be ended.Sa'ar and his National Unity party had broken with Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud party in 2020. But they joined Israel's war cabinet after October 7 and re-merged with Likud this year.Sa'ar expressed "pride" at this decision, leading to "the privilege of being part of important, sometimes bold, historic decisions".

12:35:00 Watch: Relief and joy at Hostages Square Hostages Square in Tel Aviv has played an important role in helping keep pressure on the Israeli government to secure the release of the captives held in Gaza.The families and friends of hostages have led protests in the square every week since the October 7 attacks, with images of the captives emblazoned across the area and a large digital clock counting every second they've been trapped in Gaza.Large crowds are expected to return to the square throughout today, but not in protest.Instead, they'll be celebrating the news that the hostages are due to return to Israel in the coming days.Sky News international correspondent Alex Rossi has been in the square this morning.Watch his report on the peace deal and what it means for the hostages below...

12:22:00 'Biggest uncertainty' lies in road to second phase While many welcome the progress in the first phase of Donald Trump's peace plan, the UK's former national security adviser has a warning.Sir Mark Lyall Grant said all eyes should now focus on how the plan proceeds to the second phase - see the post just below this one for more on what that entails.That, he told our presenter Matt Barbet, is the "biggest uncertainty of all"."[This] is where previous agreements of this kind have fallen back, fallen down, including in early on this year," he added. And Benjamin Netanyahu is "still under massive political pressure domestically". Watch the video below for his thoughts...

12:08:00

Explained: What will the first phase look like - and what's next?

Donald Trump announced that Israel and Hamas have agreed to the first phase of the Gaza peace plan late last night.

He said on Truth Social: "This means that ALL of the Hostages will be released very soon, and Israel will withdraw their Troops to an agreed upon line as the first steps toward a Strong, Durable, and Everlasting Peace."

We're waiting for the Israeli government to ratify a ceasefire deal - expected this evening - after which the fighting should stop.

In the meantime, here's a recap of what it is supposed to establish, according to Donald Trump's initial 20-point proposal.

### What should happen next:

- Once an agreement is ratified by both sides, a **ceasefire**will immediately come into effect; - **Israel will withdraw** within 24 hours to the agreed upon line - Hamas said this will happen tomorrow; - Within 72 hours after that, all the **Israeli hostages**, alive and dead, will be released by Hamas - Israel says this could be on Sunday or Monday; - Once all the hostages are released,**Israel will free**250 Palestinian prisoners serving life sentences and 1,700 Gazans detained after October 7; - **Humanitarian aid**entering Gaza will increase to up to 600 trucks a day, according to both sides.

### What remains pending:

- Israel's government still needs to **ratify**the agreement, which is supposed to happen at a security cabinet meeting at 3pm UK time; - The **ceasefire needs to take hold** and last beyond the release of the hostages and the prisoners for the second phase to be initiated; - Hamas said that the mediators have provided **guarantees**to assure that the agreement won't be violated once its main leverage is gone; - Hamas will have to **disarm**, according to the plan's second phase, but has not discussed this yet; - Gaza's**future governance** remains uncertain, as Hamas says it will only relinquish its rule to a Palestinian government, not the plan's international board.

**Here's a full breakdown of Trump's 20-point plan**

11:58:00 Israel to withdraw from all Gaza cities tomorrow, says Hamas official Hamas official Osama Hamdan has shared some of the details of the ceasefire agreement that has been reached.Speaking to Qatari broadcaster Al-Araby TV - cited by the Times of Israel - Hamdan said Israel's military will withdraw tomorrow from Gaza's urban areas, including Gaza City, Rafah, and Khan Younis.He said that Israel has agreed to release 1,950 Palestinian prisoners in exchange for the release of the hostages. But the exchange will not take place unless an agreement to end the war is publicly announced, he said in a statement shared on social media.According to Hamdan, mediators - which include Qatar, the US and Egypt - have provided guarantees that this agreement will not be violated.The ceasefire announcement would be left to the US side, Hamdan says.

11:25:00 'Hamas should leave the political arena', says Palestinian analyst It remains to be seen what Gaza's future governing body will actually look like, if the peace plan goes ahead as hoped.Donald Trump's proposal seeks to oust Hamas and establish a temporary international government until a reformed Palestinian Authority takes control of Gaza.All that will have to be discussed in the second phase of negotiations, says Palestinian-British analyst Yousef al Helou, speaking to our presenter Matt Barbet.But he said Hamas must "leave the political arena" as Palestinians and the world "have had enough" of the conflict.Watch the video below for his full insight...

11:12:00 In pictures: Smoke seen over Gaza after ceasefire deal announced Smoke from explosions can still be seen rising over Gaza, with Donald Trump's peace plan expected to come into effect later.The Israeli prime minister's office has said that a ceasefire will begin this evening after the deal is ratified by Israel's government.

11:01:00 Arab neighbours hope for 'just peace' and end to war after Gaza agreement Israel's Arab neighbours, including Saudi Arabia and Jordan, have now also weighed in on the deal.Saudi Arabia's foreign ministry welcomes the agreement, saying it marks an important step towards achieving a comprehensive and just peace in the region.Jordan's foreign ministry says it hopes the first-phase deal would lead to an end to the war, the withdrawal of Israeli forces, a prisoner exchange and the delivery of humanitarian aid.The foreign ministry of the United Arab Emirates - an Arab Gulf state located on the other side of the Arabian Peninsula - have also welcomed the deal and urged all parties to abide by the terms.

10:49:00 Gazans dance as they celebrate ceasefire deal news Footage shows people in Gaza dancing and celebrating news of a ceasefire deal being reached between Israel and Hamas. A group of Palestinians in Khan Younis can be seen picking up a news reporter as music plays in the background. The warring factions agreed to the first phase of US President Donald Trump's peace plan overnight, which will see hostages released and a pause in the two-year fighting.More than 67,000 Palestinians have been killed during the war, according to Gaza's Hamas-run health ministry, which does not differentiate between civilians and combatants, but says around half were women and children.Israel's bombing campaign started in response to the unprecedented 7 October 2023 attacks by Hamas, during which Israel says 1,200 people were massacred in the south and 251 were taken hostage.

newsItems.title: We Tried to Reach Gazans We Interviewed Over Two Years of War. Hereâ€™s What Happened to Them. - The New York Times
newsItems.content:
birdkit: do not modify this file

birdkit: html header automatically hoisted to the head

Weâ€™ve interviewed more than 700 people in Gaza over the past two years. Their stories stayed with us.We kept wondering: Did they find their missing relatives? Are their homes standing? Did they bury their dead? Were they forced to flee again? Were they even still alive?So we tried to find them again. This is what they said.

Weâ€™re still alive. Amir Ahmed First spoke to us in October 2023I lost them all. Ahmed al-Dalou First spoke to us in October 2024What saved my daughterâ€™s life was a miracle. Tamer Hamdan First spoke to us in June 2024Iâ€™ve lost 29 kilograms. Dr. Bakr Gaoud First spoke to us in November 2023Imagine paying $1,000 for a tent. Imagine paying for salty water. Aseel Mutair First spoke to us in March 2024I lost my children, my home, my siblings, my memories. I lost every beautiful thing in my life. Mohammed al-Aloul First spoke with us in February 2024He still has to undergo another amputation. Lubna al-Dahouk First spoke to us in November 2024Gaza has been erased. Muna Abu Holi First spoke to us in June 2024

*No single experience* can fully contain the agony of Gaza, the near-obliteration of a society and a place.

Collectively, however, the people we spoke to over the past two years have helped us see how the war has crushed those who have lived it.

They told us about the raw wounds of their grief, their fear of the next airstrike, their dread of tomorrow. About the first time they fled home as Israeli bombs and shells fell closer, the first time they put up a makeshift tent, the second time, the third.

About their weakening bodies, their children crying for bread, their days searching for baby formula and lentils. About their hopes of being evacuated for medical treatment, of going back to school, of reuniting with their families.

This article is by Vivian Yee, Lauren Leatherby, Samar Abu Elouf, Bilal Shbair, Iyad Abuheweila, Abu Bakr Bashir and Aaron Boxerman. Oct. 6, 2025

- Share full article

We tried to get back in touch with many of them. Many did not respond. Some phone numbers no longer worked. Others had escaped Gaza. Some, we learned, had been killed.

Of the nearly 100 we reached, **everyone lost something or someone**: a family member, a friend, their home, hope.

Since we last spoke, I lost two close family members. Aaed Abu Karsh First spoke to us in November 2024The loss of my daughter flashes before my eyes every day. And my husband still isnâ€™t here. Muna Abu Holi First spoke to us in June 2024I lost my father since the first interview. He was killed during the bombing. Haya Al-Barai First spoke to us in November 2024I lost a sister, a brother, and nearly 40 relatives. That alone feels like more than enough grief for one lifetime. Ismail al-Sheikh First spoke to us in January 2025I am dying every single second after I lost her. Asmaa Dwaima First spoke to us in April 2024The physical losses are devastating, but the deeper wound is mental. Al-Hassan al-Harazeen First spoke to us in January 2025Our lives are nothing but suffering on top of suffering. Weâ€™ve lost relatives and been scattered across tents. Hanaa al-Najjar First spoke to us in April 2024Last July I lost my brother, Ramadan, who was only 37. Ramadan was my backbone. Naela al-Danaf First spoke to us in November 2024We are overwhelmed by loss. Every day, someone from our family is killed. Maryam al-Kafarneh First spoke to us in November 2024I lost my money, properties, supplies, and everything. Ramy Nasr First spoke to us in November 2024I lost hope that there is an end for this nightmare. Mohammed al-Baradei First spoke to us in April 2024Yousef Sager lost his own life. He spoke to us in 2024 about surviving on boiled weeds. We later learned that he had been killed in an airstrike. First spoke to us in April 2024

Samar al-Jajaâ€™s nephews, from left, Mahmoud, Mohammed, Ahmed and Abdullah. via Samar al-Jaja

When we spoke last summer to Samar al-Jaja and her nephews, Mohammed, Mahmoud, Ahmed and Abdullah Akeila, it had been 10 months since the brothersâ€™ parents and baby sister had been killed in an airstrike.Under their tent at a charity camp, they still held out hope that they would see their parents when they were allowed to go home to Gaza City.But when they got home earlier this year, only their parentsâ€™ bedroom was still standing.There was no one inside. The five of them stood there, numb.â€œThe kids said sadly, â€˜We wish we were buried with them,â€™â€ Ms. al-Jaja, 32, said when we contacted her again recently.They have never been able to mourn properly. The sweets that people in Gaza traditionally distribute on the anniversary of a death were too expensive to make, given the wartime price of flour and sugar.They couldnâ€™t even say a prayer at their parentsâ€™ graves. They do not know where they are.â€œEven that closure has been taken from us,â€ she said.She spoke to us from a half-destroyed building in Gaza City where she and her nephews were sheltering.Days later, Israeli forces stormed the city, the latest operation in the two-year campaign against Hamas in Gaza, which began after the militant groupâ€™s deadly Oct. 7, 2023, attack on Israel.Negotiators from Israel and Hamas began holding talks in Cairo on Monday about a possible swap of Israeli hostages in Gaza for Palestinians in Israeli prisons. If they agree, the war could be one step closer to ending.But as they wait to hear what will happen to them, Palestinians in Gaza must keep trying to survive.Ms. al-Jaja and her nephews moved to another neighborhood to escape the offensive in Gaza City, then fled south. They paid nearly $4,000 to a truck driver to load half their belongings â€” it was â€œpay or risk death,â€ the driver told them, Ms. al-Jaja said.After a 14-hour journey, they ended up back in the same charity camp they were living in last year. This time, they have no tent.Almost everyone we spoke to has been displaced from homes or shelters multiple times. Many have no home to return to.

I have been displaced at least 10 times during the war. Yasser Shaban First spoke to us in October 2023I am currently living in a tent in Gaza City. We have been displaced about eight times. Wisal Abu Odeh First spoke to us in February 2024If, God forbid, an evacuation happens to my family, it would be the 10th time so far since the start of this war. Nour Barda First spoke to us in April 2024Iâ€™ve been displaced 12 times â€” four of them just since you last saw me. Naela al-Danaf First spoke to us in November 2024Sometimes my only wish is as simple as having a toilet of our own. Sanaa Abu Hilal First spoke to us in August 2025Weâ€™ve been left with this choice: die in Gaza City or be displaced to the south. It makes you feel helpless rage and humiliation. Montaser Bahja First spoke to us in January 2025Weâ€™ve been displaced four times. Layan al-Mohtaseb First spoke to us in January 2025We were displaced from 12 to 15 times. We fled from fear and indiscriminate bombardment. Abdul Hakim Abu Hatab First spoke to us in July 2025I was displaced 25 times from when I left northern Gaza on Oct. 14. Saed Abu Aita First spoke to us in August 2025I was displaced maybe eight times or more. I donâ€™t remember exactly. Mohammed Aborjela First spoke to us in October 2023When you leave your home, you feel you wonâ€™t go back ever. Ehab Fasfous First spoke to us in August 2025

Hammam Malaka and his family in their tent in Deir al-Balah this month, without their 3-year-old daughter Seela, who was killed. Bilal Shbair for The New York Times

Last October, when we wrote about Hammam Malaka and his wife, Najia Malaka, they had been separated for almost the entire war.They had gotten stuck less than 20 miles apart after Israeli troops cut off northern Gaza from southern Gaza.He was trapped in the south with Yamen, 6, and Sandy, 4. She was in the north with Seela, 3, Ashraf, the baby, and Mohammed, their newborn.When we spoke to Mr. Malaka again recently, he said they had finally managed to reunite in January, during the brief cease-fire.He told us how they found each other at what had been the border between north and south Gaza: â€œI switched on the flashlight of my old Nokia phone and began shouting into the dark â€” â€˜Ashraf! Mohammed!â€™ â€” hoping she could hear me and find me more easily,â€ he said.Then he saw her. â€œI ran and hugged her and our children with everything in me,â€ he said.But their 3-year-old, Seela, was not there. She had been killed while they were apart.After reuniting, the family returned home to Gaza City, but then were forced to flee south again.Since Israel broke the cease-fire in March, their days have been spent in a perpetual struggle against hunger and danger, which Mr. Malaka said were like â€œendless waves crashing over us.â€Without work, he said, he has taken the risk of grabbing supplies from passing aid trucks or lining up at aid distribution points.Hundreds of Palestinians have been killed searching for something to eat, according to aid officials.Many people we spoke to told us about hunger: suffering from malnutrition, losing significant weight or going days at a time without food, even as they tried desperately to find it.

We sometimes spend one or two days without eating anything at all. Nesreen Joudeh First spoke to us in December 2023I lost 20 kilograms during the time of famine. There were times when I just collapsed and could not carry injured people and run for 100 meters to reach the ambulance. Naseem Hassan First spoke to us in October 2023Our money is gone, all spent on the most basic food. Sabah Abu al-Roos First spoke to us in May 2025My children and I each lost at least 10 to 20 kilograms. Sami al-Astal First spoke to us in December 2023I lost about 25 kilograms. Mazen Alwahidi First spoke to us in April 2024Due to malnutrition, I now suffer from anemia and a deficiency of red blood cells. Wisal Abu Odeh First spoke to us in February 2024Iâ€™ve lost about 10 kilograms. Layan al-Mohtaseb First spoke to us in January 2025Getting chicken and meat is something fantastical. We only look at those foods online. Ehab Fasfous First spoke to us in August 2025My daughter Batoul and I both suffered from severe malnutrition. Safaa Zyadah First spoke to us in February 2024I once went through the nightmare of having a malnourished child. Shareef Kafarneh First spoke to us in March 2024As a mother, all I think about is how to save one meal for tomorrow, how to bring water without quarrels in the long lines. Yasmin al-Attar First spoke to us in March 2025Most of the people we knew are barely recognizable. They lost so much weight that we donâ€™t recognize their faces anymore. Ramez Souri First spoke to us in December 2024

Aead Abu Karsh and his children, from left, Huda, Jury, Nijma and Walid. Alaa Abu Karsh

Aaed Abu Karsh, 35, had managed to carve out a sliver of something like normal life when we first spoke to him last November.He was managing a shawarma place in Deir al Balah, one of the few places where ordinary life went on amid the agony all around it.In January, during the cease-fire, he moved home to Gaza City.That was the last good thing that happened, he told us recently.He lost his wifeâ€™s sister to an airstrike in June and his uncle to another strike in September. He has been displaced four times since January.Since August, he has also been injured twice: once when an airstrike hit near his house, wounding him and his wife with shrapnel, and again when he was passing a Gaza City high-rise that was bombed.â€œThe hardest thing is living with the feeling that all you can do is wait for death,â€ he said.He added: â€œNow I look at my children and wonder, will I see them alive in the months ahead? Will they be safe? And as a father, will I have the strength to protect them?â€He no longer sells shawarma to eager customers. Instead, he spends his days scrounging for food, clean water and cash to pay the astronomical prices at the markets.There have been many days when all he could bring his family was bread with cheese and thyme.â€œDaily life is another kind of war,â€ he said. â€œThis is what life has been reduced to: moving from one danger to another, trying to feed my children, trying simply to survive.â€The anguish of just getting through the day came up again and again as we spoke to people about what it feels like to live through the war.

An indescribable humiliation. Ibrahim Abdulwahed First spoke to us in January 2025I donâ€™t know when we will wake from this nightmare. Shareef Kafarneh First spoke to us in March 2024We are broken, mentally and emotionally. Hanaa al-Najjar First spoke to us in April 2024Even animals, if they were subjected to what weâ€™ve lived through, couldnâ€™t become accustomed to it. We are living through a catastrophe. Fatma Edaama First spoke to us in May 2024I have never cried as much in my life. Mkhaimar Abu Sada First spoke to us in November 2023The longer this war drags on, the heavier the pain grows. Yasmin al-Attar First spoke to us in March 2025We no longer have any strength. Weâ€™re so exhausted. Amir Ahmed First spoke to us in October 2023We have never lived through anything like this war. Sabah Abu al-Roos First spoke to us in May 2025I try to hold on to hope â€” to be the father who reassures his children, and the son who stands with his extended family. But fear and despair haunt us everywhere, as if this tragedy has no end. Amir Ahmed First spoke to us in October 2023My daughter Batoul wakes up screaming day and night from the bombings or the sound of warplanes, suffering from severe terror. Safaa Zyadah First spoke to us in February 2024We feel like chickens in a cage waiting to be slaughtered. Ehab Fasfous First spoke to us in August 2025I feel society will need 20 years to rehabilitate â€” this is horrific. Saed Abu Aita First spoke to us in August 2025You grow older and you can do nothing. This fills me with despair and sadness. Nizar Hammad First spoke to us in March 2024Every night, I lie awake wondering if tomorrow will bring anything better, or if itâ€™ll just add another layer of pain. Mohammed Shubeir First spoke to us in October 2024

Mohamed Kilani

Not everyone we tried to reach survived.Some died, or were killed, after we first spoke to them.In October 2024, when we talked to Mohamed Kilani, a lawyer in the northern Gaza town of Beit Lahia, he was barely able to feed his twin 2-year-old daughters.â€œWe have been given one option only: that is to die,â€ he told us at the time.Later, we saw social media posts from his family that mourned his death. When we reached his cousin, she said he had gone to look for food for his family and never returned.After he disappeared, family members saw some photos of stray dogs eating corpses in northern Gaza, the cousin said. They thought they recognized his body among them.Many people spoke about waiting â€” or wishing â€” for death.

Sometimes I wish we had died before witnessing all this suffering. Manal Abu Odeh First spoke to us in December 2024If I die, I want the whole world to know my dream was to live and to study. Asmaa Dwaima First spoke to us in April 2024I have nothing, no work, no food, no shelter, and no blankets. I wish I had been home when it was bombed so I could rest. Bilal Assabti First spoke to us in October 2023I wish for a missile at any moment. It would strike us all together, so that it would be better than this life. Ahmed al-Nems First spoke to us in May 2025I wished for death rather than leave my childrenâ€™s graves behind. Samar Al-Muslimi First spoke to us in July 2025All I can think about is being reunited with my children under the ground. Ahmed al-Dalou First spoke to us in October 2024You just wait for the day to end with all its hardship. My dream now is martyrdom. Mariam Moeen Awwad First spoke to us in January 2025I lost all my dreams, even the ability to think about tomorrow. Death would be easier. Aseel Mutair First spoke to us in March 2024Death would be kinder than this slow, grinding suffering. Naela al-Danaf First spoke to us in November 2024I am not afraid of anything, whether I die or live. Itâ€™s all the same. Mohammed El-Sabti First spoke to us in November 2023They want to kill us, but I donâ€™t want to die right now. I donâ€™t want to. Asmaa Dwaima First spoke to us in April 2024

Niveen Foad with four of her children, from left, Heba, Ruqaia, Awsam and Wedad. via Niveen Foad

Some people we spoke to were lucky: They managed to leave, whether by paying their way out, through their foreign passports or because they were evacuated for medical treatment.But it is a tainted prize.They all have loved ones in danger back in Gaza. And for all the safety of where they are now, it is not, in the end, home.Niveen Foad is one of them. She was the only available caretaker for her 6-year-old cousin, Sarah Yusuf, who was badly injured in an airstrike. Israel allowed Ms. Foad, her three daughters and Sarah to be evacuated to Italy in February 2024.Since we first spoke to her there, two more of her children have managed to join her in Bologna.Sarah, the 6-year-old, is doing better after intensive medical treatment, and her parents and brother have also come to Italy.Ms. Foad is learning Italian and training to be an assistant chef: moving forward.Yet thoughts of what, and who, she left behind sit heavily in her mind.â€œI feel like I betrayed my own country by leaving, but sometimes I also think that I deserve a chance in life,â€ she said. And her kids deserved that chance, she said.â€œItâ€™s a confusing and constant fight with myself,â€ she added.On the bus home from buying fish recently, she thought of her father in Gaza, who loves fish.â€œMy tears poured down, thinking I can afford to buy food and eat, but they can barely get anything,â€ she said.Italy is her present, she said. Gaza, she believes, is still her future.She wants her daughters to continue their education in Italy. But for them to get married and settle in Italy â€” impossible, she said.â€œWhatever happens, Iâ€™ll end up in Gaza,â€ she said. â€œStaying in Italy is just a temporary solution.â€We reached dozens of people who had been able to leave Gaza for places like Italy, Jordan and Egypt. Some, like Ms. Foad, were determined to go back. A few were less sure. Though physically safe, all are tormented by Gaza.Guilt claws at them, and worry keeps them up at night.

Iâ€™m sort of depressed. Sometimes I spend a week in my room without going out. Muna Abu Holi First spoke to us in June 2024I live in constant anxiety about my children and my husband in Deir al-Balah. Yasmin Joudeh First spoke to us in November 2024I am anxious because of family still in Gaza. I think about them constantly. Fatima Abu Shaar First spoke to us in November 2024I live with deep worry and stress about my family there. Abdullah Al-Hajj First spoke to us in November 2024I think too much and cannot sleep. Nesma Abu Jiyab First spoke to us in November 2024I try to stay away from people and sit alone all the time because I am constantly thinking about my mother, my sister, and my two brothers who are still in Gaza. Ruba Abu Jibba First spoke to us in November 2024I regret leaving Gaza. Lina Gamal First spoke to us in December 2024I feel like a fish out of water. Montaser al-Saafen First spoke to us in December 2024I wish I was there with them sharing their struggle, rather than watching them on TV. Maha Ashour First spoke to us in October 2024When I remember my mother, my mental state gets much worse, but when I try not to think about it, I feel a bit better. Dareen al-Bayaa First spoke to us in November 2024If I were in Gaza it would have been easier for me, because my situation would be similar to that of the people around me, but the emptiness I live in now abroad is extremely exhausting. Mohammed al-Aloul First spoke to us in February 2024Sometimes I try to tell myself that I may never meet my family there again â€” that they will all die. Maryam al-Kafarneh First spoke to us in November 2024I feel the need to have my family by my side, but I do not find them. Passant al-Louh First spoke to us in November 2024

Maher Ghanem and his wife, Fida, in May 2024. She died one month later, in June. via Maher Ghanem

When we first spoke to Maher Ghanem last year, his grief was fresh.His wife had died from cancer weeks before. She had been prevented from leaving Gaza for treatment after Israeli forces seized a crucial border crossing out of the enclave.He told us when we called him again recently that he had remarried â€” a traditional, arranged union â€” so he wouldnâ€™t have to care for his seven children alone.In September, he went to a graduation ceremony for one of his daughters, who had just nominally finished middle school. But it seemed absurd to Mr. Ghanem, he said.Realistically, his children have had almost no schooling for the last two years.His youngest son was in first grade when the war began. Now the child talks to his father about trying to make some money ferrying passengers on a donkey cart, Mr. Ghanem said.â€œThere isnâ€™t a school for him to attend, anyway,â€ he said.Mr. Ghanem, a former security officer with the Palestinian Authority, recalled attending joint Israeli-Palestinian meetings at a kibbutz in central Israel in the late 1990s.The point was to discuss how to co-exist peacefully.Those meetings, too, now seemed absurd.â€œThere isnâ€™t a glimmer of hope left in Gaza,â€ he said. â€œMe, and everyone else I know, just wants to get out.â€Many of the people we spoke to wanted to leave Gaza.Even if the war ended somehow, few still thought there was any future left for them in Gaza.

Will we still be living at the end of this, and if so, how? Suzanne Abu Daqqa First spoke to us in July 2024Displacement after displacement, famine after famine. I think this will be forever. Mohammed Al-Baradei First spoke to us in April 2024I think by the end of this war, probably all of the Gaza Strip will be wiped out. Mkhaimar Abu Sada First spoke to us in November 2023In five years, we will have to swear to people there was a city called Gaza. Mazen Alwahidi First spoke to us in April 2024The future has gone, the shop has gone, my sonsâ€™ and daughtersâ€™ future has gone, the feeling of happiness has gone. Mohammed El-Sabti First spoke to us in November 2023Gaza has no future. Muna Abu Holi First spoke to us in June 2024My children have lost their future, their education, their decent lives and their house. Ibrahim Abdulwahed First spoke to us in January 2025I dream of this war ending so I can finally sit for my high school exams â€” exams Iâ€™ve been preparing for over two years. Shahd Jweifel First spoke to us in November 2024My own dreams have shrunk to nothing more than a piece of bread and a safe corner. Ayah Jweifel First spoke to us in November 2024For me, hope is gone. Weâ€™re reliving the same year, the same suffering, over and over. Malak al-Haj Ahmed First spoke to us in January 2025I am staying for nothing. It isnâ€™t going to end. We are not doing anything â€” we are just getting killed. Mazen Alwahidi First spoke to us in April 2024We live day by day. No one thinks about the future. Mohammed Aborjela First spoke to us in October 2023My children have no schools, no education, and no health. I wait for any moment wishing to get out of Gaza. Islam al-Astal First spoke to us in December 2023I hope to leave Gaza and live with my other two brothers abroad in safety. Abdul Hakim Abu Hatab First spoke to us in July 2025But I donâ€™t want to die. I still want to grow up, become an architect, rebuild Gaza, become a football player in Palestineâ€™s national team, and win the World Cup. Mohamed Abu Rteinah First spoke to us in February 2024We donâ€™t have a present or a future. The only hope weâ€™re living with is to be able to leave. That is the only way we will give our kids a normal life. Ehab Fasfous First spoke to us in August 2025

newsItems.title: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's European return 'changes everything' for Royal Family
newsItems.content:
Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's European return 'changes everything' for Royal Family

The Duke of Sussex has made it clear he wants to spend more time in the UK

News

## Epping Council 'failed to provide suitable housing' for baby with rare genetic condition

Food

## Missed Ninja air fryers at Amazon's lowest-ever price? Black Friday-level deals are still out there

Celebrity

## ITV Big Brother star brands himself 'flag bearer of freedom of speech' as he speaks out after axe

News

## Armed gang in 'balaclavas' prompts primary school lockdown after 'threatening children'

World News

## At least 40 dead after paraglider drops bombs on Buddhist festival in echo of Oct 7 attack

Cars

## Petrol and diesel drivers face car repair costs of Â£2,800 as fuel station issue causes havoc

â€˜No point changing Ruben Amorim - there is one area Man Utd must improveâ€™ says Premier League icon

Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's return to Europe has "changed everything" for the Royal Family, sources have claimed.

The Duchess of Sussex travelled to France for Paris Fashion Week with no prior warning, marking her first visit to the continent since 2023.

Speaking about her presence, a spokesman told GB News: "Meghan, Duchess of Sussex attended the Balenciaga show in Paris on Saturday night in support of Pierpaolo Piccioli, who recently assumed the role of Creative Director for the House."This marks her first time back to the shows in over a decade. Over the years, the Duchess has worn a number of designs by Pierpaolo.

TRENDINGStoriesVideosYour Say

"They have worked closely together collaborating on design for key moments on the world stage."She has long admired his craftsmanship and modern elegance, and tonight was no different."This evening reflects the culmination of many years of artistry and friendship, reflected in her support for his new creative chapter at Balenciaga."Meghan, 44, was pictured greeting European celebrities such as Dame Anna Wintour, filmmaker Baz Luhrmann, and Mr Piccioli himself.

Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's European return 'changes everything' for Royal Family |PA / GETTY

The visit came a month after her husband, Prince Harry, returned to the UK for several charity-based events.The Duke of Sussex also reunited with his father, King Charles, for the first time since February 2024.The father and son duo had tea at Clarence House, His Majesty's London home, before Harry dashed off to his next engagement at the Gherkin.Prince Harry has made it clear that he wants to spend more time in the UK and bring his children, Prince Archie, six, and Princess Lilibet, to the country.

**LATEST ROYAL NEWS:**

- [Prince William signalling desire to â€˜break outâ€™ of royal conventions with latest move](https://www.gbnews.com/royal/prince-william-eugene-levy-royal-convention) - [Meghan appears to make statement as she travels to Europe for first time](https://www.gbnews.com/royal/meghan-markle-balenciaga-uk-snub-paris) - [Harry suffers blow as charity dropped by government](https://www.gbnews.com/royal/prince-harry-african-parks-chad)

Prince Harry seen being driven into Clarence House to meet his father | GETTY

When asked if he would like to return to the UK with his children, Harry told the Guardian: "Yes I would."This week has definitely brought that closer."With both the Duke and Duchess of Sussex making sporadic returns to Europe, royal courtiers have been left feeling uneasy, according to sources.A former royal courtier told the Daily Beast: "If they really plan to spend more time here, it changes everything.

"It puts them back in the frame, and thatâ€™s not what anyone expected."Prince Harry, 41, and Meghan stepped down as working royals in 2020 after expressing a desire to become "financially independent".The Sandringham Summit that subsequently followed resulted in the Sussexes moving permanently to the US with their son, Prince Archie.The couple were no longer allowed to represent Queen Elizabeth II through their endeavours, despite wanting to be "half-in, half-out" royals.

Harry and Meghan were originally thought to move to Canada, but eventually settled in Montecito, Santa Barbara.They welcomed their daughter, Princess Lilibet, on June 4, 2021.In 2022, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex returned to the UK for charity-based events, when the late Queen sadly died.Meghan has not returned to the UK since Queen Elizabeth II's funeral, with the Sussexes' taxpayer-funded police security being downgraded after stepping back as working royals.

Our Standards: The GB News Editorial Charter

newsItems.title: EU steel tariff hike threatens 'biggest crisis' for UK industry
newsItems.content:
# EU steel tariff hike threatens 'biggest ever crisis' for UK industry

The EU has announced plans to hike tariffs on imported steel in a move the UK's steel industry has said could be "perhaps the biggest crisis" it has ever faced.

The commission has set out plans to cut the amount of steel that can be imported into the bloc by half - beyond which the new 50% tariffs will apply.

The EU is the UK's most important export destination for steel, worth nearly Â£3bn and representing 78% of steel products made in the UK for overseas markets.

The commission has come under pressure from some member states and their steel industries, which have been struggling to compete with cheap imports from countries like China and Turkey.

The EU is proposing to reduce tariff-free quotas for imports to 18.3 million tonnes a year â€“ a 47% reduction from 2024 levels.

The new measures will come into force early next year, but will first need to be approved by the majority of EU member states and the European Parliament.

"We have global over capacity, unfair competition, state aid, and undercutting in prices and we are reacting to that", StÃ©phane SÃ©journÃ©, the European Commission's executive vice president for prosperity and industrial strategy.

"Eighteen thousand jobs were lost in the steel sector in 2024. That's too many, and we had to put a stop to that", he told a news conference at the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

The announcement is another blow to the UK steel industry, after a proposed deal to eliminate tariffs on UK steel exports to the US was put on hold indefinitely in September.

Several firms were already in dire financial straits.

The government took control of Chinese-owned plants in Scunthorpe earlier this year, while Liberty Steel plants in Rotherham and Stocksbridge collapsed into government control last month.

Speaking on his way to India on Tuesday, the prime minister said there would be "strong support" from the government for the British steel industry, which could be severely impacted by EU tariffs.

Responding to the announcement, the director general of UK Steel, Gareth Stace, said the government "must go all out to leverage our trading relationship with the European Union to secure UK country quotas or potentially face disaster".

The move by the European Union is partly a response to US President Donald Trump, who sharply raised tariffs on foreign steel earlier this year, citing concern about China and has pushed other countries to take similar steps.

Canada, Mexico and Brazil have also moved to increase protections for domestic steelmakers, responding to concerns about those firms losing business in the US while facing increased competition at home from shipments shifting from America.

Mr Stace cautioned now against the EU's measures "redirecting millions of tonnes of steel towards the UK", something which could be "terminal for many of our remaining steel companies".

The Community Union, representing UK steelworkers, called the measures an "existential threat" to the industry.

Asked about UK concerns, European trade commissioner Maros Sefcovic said at a press conference that he expected to "fully engage" with the UK on this issue, suggesting that a specific UK quota might be negotiated in the future.

In a statement, the Department for Business said it was "pushing the European Commission for urgent clarification of the impact of this move on the UK".

"It's vital we protect trade flows between the UK and EU and we will work with our closest allies to address global challenges rather than adding to our industries' woes", Industry Minister Chris McDonald said.

"This government has shown its commitment to our steel industry by securing preferential access to the US market for our exporters, and we continue to explore stronger trade measures to protect UK steel producers from unfair behaviours."

The government said the industry minister will meet steel representatives on Thursday to discuss their concerns.

Kathleen Van Brempt, vice-chair of the European Parliament's committee on global trade, said she will advocate for the UK in the coming days, adding "the UK for us is a very close ally".

## A big blow

Liam Bates is UK managing director at Marcegaglia in Sheffield, which makes stainless steel products and exports to the EU. He said the announcement was a "big blow".

"It must be amongst the biggest challenges we've faced for a very long time. Now the big question is on the detail. Will there be any deal done by the UK government to soften the blow?"

"We have no tariffs on Europe themselves, so you would expect some reciprocity on that, so that we are not treated in the same way. That's the detail we're hoping the government should work towards", he said.

In the meantime, he said future trade with EU customers is a concern.

"We have good relationships with our customers, and we will be communicating with them, but it puts a strain on our business immediately."

"Our customers are in there for the long term, and so there will be a question over whether there's a long-term relationship that can still be had in the face of these quotas."

## What tariffs has Trump announced and why?

## UK hopes for 0% tariff on steel exports to US dashed

Wednesday 10 September

Text content

**State of the European Union debate**

Filling the morningâ€™s agenda, the annual parliamentary State of the European Union debate is a key opportunity for MEPs to hold the European Commission to account. In her opening statement, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen will detail both the Commissionâ€™s achievements over the past year and current challenges. The political group leaders will then steer the debate, with members assessing the Commissionâ€™s work and its plans, while also presenting their own priorities. You can [follow President von der Leyenâ€™s speech and the debate with MEPs](https://multimedia.europarl.europa.eu/en/webstreaming/debate-on-state-of-european-union-2025-with-nametags-of-speakers_20250910-0900-SPECIAL-OTHER) from 09.00.

Ahead of the debate, at 08.45, European Parliament President Roberta Metsola will give a doorstep statement in the media stand-up area by the hemicycle in Strasbourg. You can follow this live via [EP webstreaming](https://multimedia.europarl.europa.eu/en/webstreaming/doorstep-by-roberta-metsola-ep-president-prior-to-debate-on-state-of-european-union_20250910-0845-SPECIAL-OTHER) and the [European Broadcasting Service](https://audiovisual.ec.europa.eu/en/ebs/grid?ebs=yes&ebsplus=yes&date=20250910).

**Andreas KLEINER****(+32) 498 98 33 22****Estefania NARRILLOS****(+32) 498 98 39 85****@EuroParlPress**

**EU-US trade relations**

In a debate starting at about 14.30 with Trade Commissioner MaroÅ¡ Å efÄoviÄ and Danish European Affairs Minister Marie Bjerre for the Council, MEPs will assess the implementation of the EU-US trade deal and the prospect of wider EU trade agreements.

**Lieven COSIJN(+32) 473 864 141 @EP_Trade**

**Updated rules on package holidays**

Members will discuss changes to the Package Travel Directive with Consumer Protection Commissioner Michael McGrath from around 17.00. The updated directive will refine travellersâ€™ information and trip cancellation rights, as well as their rights to a refund and repatriation help, if their travel organiser should go bankrupt or unforeseen circumstances disrupt their holiday plans. The vote on Parliamentâ€™s negotiating position is scheduled for Thursday.

**Maris KURME****(+32) 477 99 06 65****@EP_SingleMarket**

**In brief**

**Migration.**This monthâ€™s topical debate, on migration, will begin at 13.30, after the votes.

**Global satellite navigation system interference.**In a debate with Commissioner for Defence and Space Andrius Kubilius, starting at around 17.30, Parliament will debate threats to aviation and maritime transport and the urgent need to build resilience against spoofing and jamming.

**Slovakia.**MEPs will discuss the rule of law situation and possible misuse of EU funds in Slovakia, in a debate with Commissioner Michael McGrath and Marie Bjerre, Danish Minister for European Affairs, from about 18.30.

**Taxation of large digital platforms**. In an evening debate, Commissioner McGrath will respond to an oral question on the implications of international developments for EU policy on taxing the digital economy.

**Human rights.** In evening debates with Commissioner Jozef SÃ­kela, MEPs will discuss the cases of EU citizens detained in the occupied areas of Cyprus, political prisoner Victoire Ingabire in Rwanda, and Irish national Abdoul Aziz Goma, arbitrarily detained in Togo. Three separate resolutions will be put to a vote in plenary on Thursday.

**Votes**

At noon, MEPs will vote, among others, on:

- simplifying and strengthening the carbon border adjustment mechanism; - cohesion policy, including the mid-term review; - facilitating investments and reforms to boost European competitiveness and on creating a capital markets union, one year after the Draghi Report; - the future of agriculture and the post-2027 common agricultural policy, and - a motion for a resolution on strengthening Moldovaâ€™s resilience against Russian hybrid threats and malign interference.

Live coverage of the plenary session can be found on [Parliamentâ€™s webstreaming site](https://multimedia.europarl.europa.eu/en/webstreaming/plenary-session_20250910-0900-PLENARY) and on [EbS+](https://audiovisual.ec.europa.eu/en/ebs/grid?ebs=no&ebsplus=yes&date=20250910).

For detailed information on the session, please also see our [newsletter](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/agenda/briefing/2025-09-08) and the [detailed agenda](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/OJQ-10-2025-09-10_EN.html).

Find more [information regarding plenary](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/plenary/en/home.html).

newsItems.title: Burkina Fasoâ€™s military govâ€™t arrests European NGO workers for â€˜spyingâ€™ | Human Rights News | Al Jazeera
newsItems.content:
Burkina Fasoâ€™s military govâ€™t arrests European NGO workers for â€˜spyingâ€™ | Human Rights News | Al Jazeera

Burkina Faso President Ibrahim Traore arrives to the Grand Palace at the Kremlin in Moscow, Russia, on May 10, 2025 [Stanislav Krasilnikov/RIA Novosti via AP]

By Lyndal Rowlands and AFPPublished On 8 Oct 20258 Oct 2025Click here to share on social mediashare2SharefacebooktwitterwhatsappcopylinkSave

Burkina Fasoâ€™s military government says it has arrested eight people working for a humanitarian organisation, accusing them of â€œspying and treasonâ€, allegations the Dutch nonprofit â€œcategoricallyâ€ rejected.

Burkina Fasoâ€™s Security Minister Mahamadou Sana said the eight people arrested worked for the International NGO Safety Organisation (INSO), a Netherlands-based group specialising in humanitarian safety.

## Recommended Stories

list of 4 items

- list 1 of 4[Burkina Faso bans homosexuality as a crime punishable with prison, fines](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/9/2/burkina-faso-bans-homosexuality-as-a-crime-punishable-with-prison-fines) - list 2 of 4[Military-run Niger, Mali and Burkina Faso announce joint ICC withdrawal](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/9/23/military-run-niger-mali-and-burkina-faso-announce-joint-icc-withdrawal) - list 3 of 4[The US and Russiaâ€™s proxy war is bleeding Africa](https://www.aljazeera.com/opinions/2025/9/25/the-us-and-russias-proxy-war-is-bleeding-africa) - list 4 of 4[Trial opens for ex-Mali PM jailed by military rulers over â€˜solidarityâ€™ post](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/9/29/trial-opens-for-ex-mali-pm-jailed-by-military-rulers-over-solidarity-post)

end of list

Those detained included a French man, a French-Senegalese woman, a Czech man, a Malian and four Burkinabe nationals, Sana said, alleging the staff members had continued working for the organisation after it was banned for three months, for allegedly â€œcollecting sensitive data without authorisationâ€.

The security minister claimed some of INSOâ€™s staff had â€œcontinued to clandestinely or covertly conduct activities such as information collection and meetings in person or onlineâ€ following the ban, including its country director, who had also previously been arrested when the suspension came into effect at the end of July.

Sana said the INSO staff members had â€œcollected and passed on sensitive security information that could be detrimental to national security and the interests of Burkina Faso, to foreign powersâ€.

The Hague-based humanitarian organisation issued a statement on Tuesday saying it â€œcategoricallyâ€ rejected the allegations about its activities in Burkina Faso.

â€œ[We] remain committed to doing everything in our power to secure the safe release of all our colleagues,â€ INSO said in the statement.

Advertisement

INSO also said it collects information â€œexclusively for the purpose of keeping humanitarians safe,â€ and that the information it gathers â€œis not confidential and is largely already known to the public.â€

Burkina Fasoâ€™s military government has turned away from the West and, in particular, its former colonial ruler, France, since seizing power in a September 2022 coup.

Together with neighbouring Mali and Niger, which are also ruled by military governments, it has also withdrawn from regional and international organisations in recent months, with the three countries [forming their own bloc](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/9/23/military-run-niger-mali-and-burkina-faso-announce-joint-icc-withdrawal) known as the Alliance of Sahel States.

The three West African countries have also wound back defence cooperation with Western powers, most notably their former colonial ruler, [France](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/9/19/france-suspends-counterterrorism-cooperation-with-mali), in favour of closer ties with Russia, including Niger nationalising a uranium mine operated by French nuclear firm [Orano](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/6/21/niger-revokes-french-nuclear-groups-licence-at-major-uranium-mine).

Within the three countries, the military governments are fighting armed groups linked to al-Qaeda that control territory and have staged attacks on army posts.

Human Rights Watch and other advocacy groups have accused the fighters, the military and partner forces of Burkina Faso and Mali of possible atrocities.

newsItems.content:
European Parliament

END OF REFACTORING

# State of the EU: Security, Ukraine, Gaza, Competitiveness, EU-US trade

Press Releases Plenary session 10-09-2025 - 13:27

## Share this page:

- Facebook - X - LinkedIn - WhatsApp

MEPs debated the State of the European Union with Commission President von der Leyen Â© European Union 2025 â€“ EP

In the annual State of the European Union debate, MEPs quizzed President von der Leyen on the Commissionâ€™s work since the beginning of its new mandate and its upcoming plans.

Text content

Opening the debate, EP President Roberta Metsola said: â€œIn these unprecedented times, we need clarity and we need resolve to steer Europe. We need a Europe that takes responsibility for its own security, makes it easier for businesses, and protects jobs. A Europe which is fairer and one that stands up for our democratic values. When the world feels too often like it is on fire, with Russian aggression against Ukraine and the horrific situation in Gaza, this Parliament is eager for Europe to step up with new and bold ideas.â€ â€œThis must be Europeâ€™s independence momentâ€, said Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. Europe must be able to take care of its own defence and security, control the technologies and energies that will fuel its economies, decide what kind of society and democracy we want to live in and be open to the world. On Ukraine, von der Leyen announced plans to turn up the pressure on Russia with a 19th package of sanctions and a faster phase-out of Russian fossil fuels. The Commission will also propose a â€œQualitative Military Edgeâ€ programme to support investment in the Ukrainian armed forces, and an â€œEastern Flank Watchâ€ initiative to provide Europe with independent strategic capabilities. â€œEurope stands in full solidarity with Poland", she said with regard to the â€œreckless and unprecedentedâ€ violation of Polandâ€™s and Europe's airspace by Russian drones. Speaking about the war in Gaza, von der Leyen said that â€œman-made famine can never be a weapon of war. For the sake of the children, for the sake of humanity â€“ this must stop.â€ She announced the Commissionâ€™s intention to â€œput our bilateral support to Israel on holdâ€, propose sanctions on extremist ministers and violent settlers, and impose a partial suspension of the Association Agreement on trade-related matters. Europeâ€™s goal must be â€œreal security for Israel and a safe present and future for all Palestinians. And that means that the hostages must be releasedâ€, she stressed. On competitiveness and the single market, President von der Leyen stressed that a digital euro and the savings and investments union will make it easier for companies and consumers alike. She announced a multi-billion euro â€œScaleup Europe Fundâ€ to make major investments in young, fast-growing companies in critical tech areas, a â€œBattery Boosterâ€ package to boost production in Europe, a â€œQuality Jobs Actâ€ and a European anti-poverty strategy to help eradicate poverty by 2050. Regarding the trade agreement with the United States, she said: â€œWe have the best agreement, without any doubtâ€, providing crucial stability and preventing a full-fledged trade war. Political group speakers Manfred Weber (EPP, DE) thanked the Commission for delivering on many fronts, from cutting red tape to strengthening EU defence and reducing illegal migration. He promised to continue supporting the Commissionâ€™s work by backing the EU-US and Mercosur trade deals, when the alternative would be a trade war. On the green deal, he argued the EUâ€™s climate approach needs to be realistic and support technological neutrality. He also urged fellow MEPs to accelerate work on a range of EU files and to avoid ideological fights. â€œWhere is Europe?â€ asked Iratxe GarcÃ­a (S&D, ES), adding that urgency and unity cannot supersede Europe's ambition and the advancement of its own interests. GarcÃ­a criticised the â€œunfair and unacceptableâ€ trade deal with the US and announced her determination to amend it. â€œAnd where is Europe when Gaza is dying?â€ she added, saying the proposed suspension of cooperation with Israel comes too late. Jordan Bardella (PfE, FR) condemned President von der Leyenâ€™s support for the Mercosur free trade deal. He criticised the EUâ€™s proposal to lower tariffs on Chinese vehicles, as well as energy market rules that disregard Franceâ€™s low-cost nuclear advantage. Bardella criticised the trade agreement with the U.S., which he said sacrifices key French industriesâ€”defence, wine, luxury goods, and pharmaceuticalsâ€”while smaller nations secure better deals. ECR Group Co-Chair Nicola Procaccini (IT) said that Europe â€œmust strengthen our values, our economy and our alliesâ€, adding that his group supports the tariff agreement with the US â€œbecause it is better than a trade war between allies who need each otherâ€. He stated the Green Deal â€œis today too high an obstacle for European competitivenessâ€ and applauded recent proposals on migration policy, calling for returns to be made an effective practice. Valerie Hayer (Renew, FR) warned that the EU is losing Europeans' trust because it has become too weak to defend them. She called for a more integrated, sovereign and federal EU. She warned that the EU faced an existential culture war, threatening the European way of life, its peoples' freedoms and their independence. She called for more practical action on the Democracy Shield and competitiveness, and on combating the belligerence of Russia and Israel. She concluded by calling for a convention to reform the EU. Bas Eickhout (Greens/EFA, NL) called for Europe to â€œstop thinking as a market and start thinking as a powerâ€. It should show confidence, he added, demanding immediate action to address the situation in Gaza. Security also means acting on climate change, according to Eickhout, who called for investment, in European renewables and other industries to fight autocrats, but also in the European workforce, education, infrastructure and green innovation, to improve European competitiveness. Martin Schirdewan (The Left, DE) called the trade deal with the US a â€œtotal capitulation. He linked free trade policies to rising poverty, job losses, and rising costs, with billions invested in militarisation alongside â€œbrutal cutsâ€ in pensions and welfare. He denounced the EUâ€™s silence on the humanitarian crisis and war crimes committed by the Israeli military in Gaza, accusing it of double standards in foreign policy and of failing to play a meaningful role in forging peace. RenÃ© Aust (ESN, DE) said that, while markets are growing everywhere in the world, Europe is falling behind due to a lack of entrepreneurial freedom. He also blamed migration policy for increased violence, criminal gangs, drugs, and issues with the safety of women in Europe. You can watch the full debate here.

newsItems.content:
# Asian stocks today: Markets trade mixed as investors assess AI outlook; Nikkei gains over 600 points, HSI down 0.1%

Asian markets were mixed on Thursday as investors tried to assess the global AI-driven rally, US interest rate moves, and the continuing government shutdown in Washington.Japan's Nikkei gained 1.29% or 614 points trading at 48,349, while HSI dipped 9 points or 0.03% to reach 26,820 at 9:30 AM IST.Tired of too many ads?go ad free nowIn India, NSE benchmark Nifty traded flat, adding 35 points or 0.14 to trade at 25,081.Some relief came from the Middle East, where Israel and Hamas agreed on the first phase of a ceasefire in Gaza. The news helped calm fears over oil supply, sending prices lower, while gold eased slightly after hitting a record above $4,000 an ounce on Wednesday.Tech companies have soared this year, with huge investments in AI driving stock markets higher.But worries are rising that the profits may not match the money being spent, raising concerns about a bubble in the sector."AI is clearly a bubble," said Neil Wilson of Saxo Markets.However, despite these concerns, Wall Street bounced back after Oracleâ€™s report, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq closing at new records on Wednesday.In Asia, optimism boosted Tokyo, which rose over 1 percent after business-friendly Sanae Takaichi was elected leader of Japanâ€™s ruling party, fuelling hopes of further stimulus.Shanghai rose as markets reopened after a week-long holiday, while Sydney, Taipei, and Manila also gained. Hong Kong, Singapore, Wellington, and Jakarta fell.The US government shutdown continued to weigh on sentiment. Democrats blocked a sixth Republican attempt at a stopgap funding measure, insisting that any deal must include an extension of healthcare subsidies for 24 million people.On the geopolitical front, Donald Trump unveiled a 20-point peace plan as part of the Gaza ceasefire.Tired of too many ads?go ad free nowUnder the deal, Hamas would release all hostages, and Israeli troops would pull back to a pre-agreed line.Oil prices, which had been elevated over supply worries, eased. Gold, which surged to nearly $4,060 an ounce on Wednesday due to the crisis, also retreated.In company news, Hong Kong-listed Hang Seng Bank surged over 26% after reports that HSBC plans to take it private, buying remaining shares in a deal valuing the lender at US$37 billion. Meanwhile, HSBC shares fell more than 6%.

The primary focus of the TOI Business Desk is to keep a watchful eye on the global business landscape, covering a wide spectrum of industries, markets, economic trends, in-depth analysis, exclusive reports and breaking stories that impact businesses and economies. newsItems.title: Asian shares are mostly lower after US stocks retreat - ABC News
newsItems.content:
# Asian shares are mostly lower after US stocks retreat

Shares are mostly lower in Asia after Wall Street snapped a long streak of records

Shares were mostly lower in Asia on Wednesday after U.S. stocks sank to their first loss in eight days, losing momentum after the price of gold topped $4,000 per ounce for the first time.

The price of gold was up $25.40 at $4,029.60 an ounce. U.S. futures and oil prices also advanced.

The Japanese yen fell sharply against the dollar on expectations that Sanae Takaichi, the conservative lawmaker likely to become the next prime minister, will push to keep interest rates low.

The dollar rose to 152.53 yen from 151.90 yen, while the euro slipped to $1.1621 from $1.1659.

Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 edged 0.1% higher to 48,002.18.

Takaichi, who the ruling Liberal Democrats chose as their leader last weekend, is expected to increase spending and to advocate for easier credit, possibly slowing efforts by the Bank of Japan to raise its key interest rate. It has remained near zero for years, even as inflation has exceeded its target of about 2%, outpacing wage increases.

â€œWhile the economic case for tighter monetary policy remains intact, we suspect that the Bank of Japan will use the pressure by Japanâ€™s incoming government as an opportunity to delay rate hikes until January,â€ Marcel Thieliant of Capital Economics said in a commentary.

Lawmakers in Japan's lower house of parliament are due to elect a successor to Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba later this month. The Liberal Democrats hold the most seats despite not having an outright majority, so Takaishi is expected to become the country's first female prime minister.

Elsewhere in Asia, Hong Kong's Hang Seng dropped 0.9% to 26,719.68 and the S&P/ASX 200 edged 0.1% lower to 8,945.10.

Markets in mainland China and South Korea were closed for holidays.

In Taiwan, the Taiex lost 1%.

On Tuesday, the S&P 500 fell 0.4% from its all-time high, closing at 6,714.59. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 0.2% to 46,602.98, and the Nasdaq composite gave up 0.7% to 22,788.36.

## Government shutdown updates: IRS to furlough nearly half its staff

## Central witness undermines case against Comey, prosecutors concluded: Sources

## Sniper opens fire on Dallas ICE facility, killing 1 detainee, wounding 2: DHS

- Sep 24, 6:39 PM

Tesla was the heaviest weight on the market and dropped 4.4% after unveiling cheaper versions of two of its electric car models. The stock gave back most of its leap from the prior day, when speculation and hype built after Tesla hinted at a coming product announcement.

Oracle also helped drag the market lower. It fell 2.5% after a news report suggested itâ€™s making thin profit margins on a key line of business related to artificial-intelligence technology.

U.S. shares have rushed higher in recent months on hopes that the economy will remain resilient and that the Federal Reserve will continue to cut interest rates.

The rapid rise of artificial intelligence has helped fan buying enthusiasm, but also is raising worries that share prices may have shot too high.

On Tuesday, Dell climbed 3.5% after executives talked up the companyâ€™s opportunity for growth because of AI at an investment conference. Advanced Micro Devices rallied 3.8% to add to its surge from Monday, when it announced a deal where OpenAI will use its chips to power AI infrastructure. IBM rose 1.5% after announcing a partnership that will integrate Anthropicâ€™s Claude AI chatbot into some of its software products.

Much is riding on expectations that the AI investment boom will pay off by making the global economy more productive and driving more growth. Without that increased efficiency, inflation could push higher due to upward pressure coming from the mountains of debt that the U.S. and other governments worldwide are building.

Investors have traditionally seen gold as a hedge against high inflation. Its price has soared more than 50% this year because of governmentsâ€™ huge debt loads, political uncertainties and anticipation that the Fed will cut interest rates.

Also early Wednesday, U.S. benchmark crude oil was up 52 cents at $62.25 per barrel. Brent crude, the international standard, rose 50 cents to $65.95 per barrel.

___

AP Business Writer Stan Choe contributed.

newsItems.title: Asian hornet nest removal in Sark to force road closure
newsItems.content:
# Asian hornet nest removal to force road closure

A road is set to be closed for a few hours later while an Asian hornet nest is removed.

Sark Police said a team would be working on the island from 10:30 to 13:30 BST to remove the nest between the Cider Barn to St Peter's Church.

"Please support the removal team by keeping out of their way and giving them space to perform this taxing operation," a police spokesperson said on Facebook.

Asian hornets were first reported on the Channel Islands in 2016 and are an invasive species which damage biodiversity by feeding on native bees and wasps.
